findings.title: Reentrancy vulnerability in CashOut
findings.explanation: The contract calls `msg.sender.call.value(_am)()` before updating the user balance. An attacker can reenter the CashOut function in their fallback and withdraw more funds than they have.
findings.fix_suggestion: Use the Checks-Effects-Interactions pattern: deduct the balance before making the external call, or use `transfer`/`send` instead of `call.value`, and consider using ReentrancyGuard.

findings.title: Silent failure for deposits below MinDeposit
findings.explanation: If a user calls Deposit with `msg.value` less than `MinDeposit`, the function returns without reverting, but the Ether is still accepted by the contract and locked with no credit to the user.
findings.fix_suggestion: Require `msg.value >= MinDeposit` and revert on failure so that too-small deposits are refunded automatically.

findings.title: Denial of service via untrusted Log contract
findings.explanation: Both Deposit and CashOut invoke an external logging contract (`TransferLog.AddMessage`). If the log contract reverts or consumes excessive gas, it can block deposits or withdrawals.
findings.fix_suggestion: Decouple logging from core logic: emit native Solidity events instead of making external calls, or handle logging failures gracefully without reverting the main flow.

findings.title: Unchecked integer arithmetic for balances
findings.explanation: The contract uses `+=` and `-=` on `balances[msg.sender]` without checking for overflows or underflows. A maliciously large deposit could overflow the balance mapping.
findings.fix_suggestion: Use SafeMath library for all arithmetic operations to ensure proper overflow and underflow checks.

unmatched_predictions.title: Silent failure for deposits below MinDeposit
Denial of service via untrusted Log contract
